prop.head.headtext: Confidential Business Information in Historical Context

para.paratext: Copyright subsists in Canada in every original literary, dramatic, musical and artistic work. A work is considered to be “original” if the thought derives from the author, was not copied from some other work and has not been in the public domain.[1]

“Literary work” is defined by s. 2[2] of the Act as including, inter alia, tables, compilations and computer programs. The case law has interpreted the words “literary work” to cover a much wider field and include all works which are expressed in print or in writing irrespective of their literary quality or style. However, the Copyright Act does not protect ideas, procedures, processes, systems, methods of operation, concepts, principles or discoveries.[3]

Difficult questions of fact frequently arise when dealing with compilations, since they are made up of a considerable quantity of non-original material. However, the originality of the parts is immaterial as long as the work as a whole is original. The originality of the work is determined by the degree of labour and skill used such that the end product has some character or quality which the elements or raw material did not possess and which differentiates the product from the raw material.[4]

A creator obtains copyright upon creation of a work, and protection does not depend on the creator taking any formal steps to protect it. Copyright law protects the expression of original information in a tangible form. The work does not need to be a commercial or industrial work. Once a work is protected by copyright, it cannot lose that protection. Copyright encompasses the exclusive right to make copies. An author does not lose the right simply by widely distributing copies of the work.[5]

A work may be a copyright work and be confidential at the same time. However, in order for there to be an infringement of copyright, there must be a restricted act such as reproduction. Furthermore, the form of the idea, not the idea itself, must have been copied.
Copyright Act, R.S.C. 1985, c. C-42, s. 2; Viceroy Homes Ltd. v. Ventury Homes Ltd. (1991), 43 C.L.R. 312, 34 C.P.R. (3d) 385 (Ont. Ct. (Gen. Div.)), affd 69 C.P.R. (3d) 459 (Ont. C.A.).
